Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: There are ______ times the amount of livestock as there are people on the plant
Options: A. 2, B. 4, C. 6, D. 8
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated reduction in greenhouse gas emissions if all meat were to be removed from our shelves? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 63%, D. 80% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary reason for the increase in produce costs immediately after the removal of meat? Options: A. Decrease in demand for fruits and vegetables, B. Increase in transportation costs, C. Rise in demand for fruits and vegetables, D. Decrease in crop yields Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the impact on the meat industry workers in developing countries after the collapse of the meat industry? Options: A. They are shifted to higher-paying jobs, B. They are left scrambling for income, C. They are unaffected by the change, D. They are shifted to agricultural crops Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the long-term effect on the cost of vegetarianism compared to meat-eating in most countries? Options: A. Vegetarianism becomes more expensive, B. Vegetarianism becomes less expensive, C. The cost remains the same, D. The cost is dependent on the region Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the impact on land use after the removal of animals raised for meat? Options: A. More land is required for agriculture, B. Less land is required for agriculture, C. The same amount of land is required for agriculture, D. Land is converted to urban areas Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is one of the health benefits of a meatless diet? Options: A. Lower rates of heart disease, B. Higher rates of cancer, C. Increased risk of respiratory diseases, D. Decreased risk of influenza Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the impact on global biodiversity after the removal of animals raised for meat? Options: A. Global biodiversity decreases, B. Global biodiversity remains the same, C. Global biodiversity rises, D. The impact is dependent on the region Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary reason for the increase in global temperatures even if fossil fuel burning is stopped? Options: A. Business as usual food systems paired with a growing population, B. Increase in vegetarian diets, C. Decrease in meat consumption, D. Increase in renewable energy sources Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the estimated percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is one way to achieve the benefits of a meatless world without completely removing meat from our diets? Options: A. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk consumption, B. Increasing chicken consumption, C. Decreasing fish consumption, D. Increasing dairy consumption Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the topic of livestock and numbers.

The most similar generated MCQ is not available, but Question 9 is somewhat related to the topic of livestock. However, it does not match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose, I would say that none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ, but if you'd like, I can try to create a new MCQ that is more similar.

That being said, if you'd like to create a new MCQ that is more similar, here is an example:

Generated MCQ:
Question: There are approximately ______ times as many livestock as people.
Options: A. 2, B. 4, C. 6, D. 8
Correct Option: B

This new generated MCQ is more similar to the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A meat-free diet requires less land and water than a meat-filled diet.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated reduction in greenhouse gas emissions if all meat were to be removed from our shelves? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 63%, D. 80% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary reason for the increase in produce costs immediately after the removal of meat? Options: A. Decrease in demand for fruits and vegetables, B. Increase in transportation costs, C. Rise in demand for fruits and vegetables, D. Decrease in crop yields Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the impact on the meat industry workers in developing countries after the collapse of the meat industry? Options: A. They are shifted to higher-paying jobs, B. They are left scrambling for income, C. They are unaffected by the change, D. They are shifted to agricultural crops Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the long-term effect on the cost of vegetarianism compared to meat-eating in most countries? Options: A. Vegetarianism becomes more expensive, B. Vegetarianism becomes less expensive, C. The cost remains the same, D. The cost is dependent on the region Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the impact on land use after the removal of animals raised for meat? Options: A. More land is required for agriculture, B. Less land is required for agriculture, C. The same amount of land is required for agriculture, D. Land is converted to urban areas Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is one of the health benefits of a meatless diet? Options: A. Lower rates of heart disease, B. Higher rates of cancer, C. Increased risk of respiratory diseases, D. Decreased risk of influenza Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the impact on global biodiversity after the removal of animals raised for meat? Options: A. Global biodiversity decreases, B. Global biodiversity remains the same, C. Global biodiversity rises, D. The impact is dependent on the region Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary reason for the increase in global temperatures even if fossil fuel burning is stopped? Options: A. Business as usual food systems paired with a growing population, B. Increase in vegetarian diets, C. Decrease in meat consumption, D. Increase in renewable energy sources Correct Option: None

Question 10: What is one way to achieve the benefits of a meatless world without completely removing meat from our diets? Options: A. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk consumption, B. Increasing chicken consumption, C. Decreasing fish consumption, D. Increasing dairy consumption Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

More land is required for agriculture, B. Less land is required for agriculture, C. The same amount of land is required for agriculture, D. Land is converted to urban areas.

This question is similar in intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which states that a meat-free diet requires less land and water than a meat-filled diet. Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a benefit of transitioning less or no meat?
Options: A. Less disease, B. Less cost, C. Increase health and life expectancy, D. More biodiversity, E. Higher crop yields, F. Oceans species rebound from overfishing, G. Lower greenhouse gas emissions, H. All of the above
Correct Option: None

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated reduction in greenhouse gas emissions if all meat were to be removed from our shelves? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 63%, D. 80% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary reason for the increase in produce costs immediately after the removal of meat? Options: A. Decrease in demand for fruits and vegetables, B. Increase in transportation costs, C. Rise in demand for fruits and vegetables, D. Decrease in crop yields Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the impact on the meat industry workers in developing countries after the collapse of the meat industry? Options: A. They are shifted to higher-paying jobs, B. They are left scrambling for income, C. They are unaffected by the change, D. They are shifted to agricultural crops Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the long-term effect on the cost of vegetarianism compared to meat-eating in most countries? Options: A. Vegetarianism becomes more expensive, B. Vegetarianism becomes less expensive, C. The cost remains the same, D. The cost is dependent on the region Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the impact on land use after the removal of animals raised for meat? Options: A. More land is required for agriculture, B. Less land is required for agriculture, C. The same amount of land is required for agriculture, D. Land is converted to urban areas Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is one of the health benefits of a meatless diet? Options: A. Lower rates of heart disease, B. Higher rates of cancer, C. Increased risk of respiratory diseases, D. Decreased risk of influenza Correct Option: None

Question 9: What is the estimated percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: None

Increasing chicken consumption, C. Decreasing fish consumption, D. Increasing dairy consumption Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 7: What is the impact on global biodiversity after the removal of animals raised for meat?**

However, this question only addresses one aspect of the ground truth MCQ. A more comprehensive match would be a question that encompasses multiple benefits of transitioning to a meatless world.

A closer match is not available among the generated MCQs, but if I had to choose one that could potentially be modified to include all the benefits, I would suggest:

**Question 7** could be modified to include more options and address the broader scope of the ground truth MCQ.

However, if I had to choose another question that might be a better match in its current form, I would suggest:

**Question 10: What is one way to achieve the benefits of a meatless world without completely removing meat from our diets?**

This question does not directly address the benefits but rather a way to achieve them. It is not a perfect match but is the closest among the generated MCQs in terms of discussing the broader implications of a meatless world.

To create a better match, I would suggest generating a new question that includes multiple benefits of a meatless world, such as:

**New Question: What are the benefits of transitioning to a meatless world?**

Options: A. Less disease, B. Less cost, C. Increase health and life expectancy, D. More biodiversity, E. Higher crop yields, F. Oceans species rebound from overfishing, G. Lower greenhouse gas emissions, H. All of the above

This new question would be a more direct match for the ground truth MCQ.

Given the available options, I will choose **Question 7** as the most similar generated MCQ, but with the understanding that it only partially addresses the scope of the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: **7**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless

than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk

of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Beef and dairy production are responsible for more than ___ of all food based emissions, while providing about ___ of the world's nutrients.
Options: A. 30%, 1%, B. 40%, 4%, C. 50%, 8%, D. 60%, 18%
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Let's explore a hypothetical together. There are over four times as
many livestock as people. Farmed cattle alone weigh
nearly ten times as much as all wild mammals combined. So imagine if a wizard of meatless
dining suddenly appeared and with one wave of a wand wiped
away all meat from our shelves— along with any desire to eat it. Farm animals destined for food vanish—
whisked away to another planet. What happens in the following days,
years, and even millennia? Overnight, food related greenhouse gas
emissions drop by about 63%. We no longer get protein
and key nutrients from the approximately
70 billion chickens, 1.5 billion pigs, 300 million cattle, and 200 million tons
of fish and shellfish processed for consumption each year. To help fill this nutritional gap, our demand for fruits, vegetables,
and legumes go up— a diet that most dietitians agree contains
all of the nutrients we need for a healthy life. But initially there aren’t enough
of these foods to go around. The rise in demand causes
produce costs to soar. In regions like Mongolia, where the harsh environment makes
it difficult to grow vegetables, a sudden lack of meat leaves
people with little to eat. Cultures built around meat
lose their foundations. Members of salmon-eating tribes in the
Pacific Northwest of the United States, for example, lose not only
sustenance and livelihoods, but an integral component
of their religion. Tens of millions of anglers lose work
that was already threatened by dwindling fish populations. As the meat industry collapses, many households in developing countries
are left scrambling for income that once came from livestock farming. Some meat producers shift
to agricultural crops, which leave workers—
and neighboring communities— less susceptible to respiratory diseases
associated with livestock production. As crop agriculture expands,
prices come down. Ultimately, vegetarianism becomes less
expensive than meat-eating in most countries. Luckily, we don’t need to clear
new farmland to grow all this food. Without animals raised for meat, land that had been used to grow
feed is now available. All things considered,
our new diets require less land and water. Millions of deaths are avoided every year, thanks in part to lower rates
of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated
with red meat consumption. We no longer contract new pathogens
from wild animals hunted for food, or novel influenza viruses
from farmed pigs, or drug-resistant superbugs that develop
in beef cattle that have been preemptively
fed antibiotics. As the years pass,
global biodiversity rises as habitat loss, pesticide use, and other
pressures from agriculture subside. Amazonian birds have more
forest to fly over. Fewer cheetahs are shot for stalking
too close to livestock. Bee, wasp, and butterfly communities
thrive as natural areas expand. In turn, insect-pollinated crops
produce higher yields. Many ocean species rebound
from overfishing. Throughout history,
humans in traditionally vegetarian regions have evolved a genetic mutation that helps them more efficiently
process fats from plants. So over thousands of years, our bodies may evolve to make
the most of our veggies. Or we may lose some adaptations, like the
ability to extract iron from meat. Of course, a wizard will not
turn our world meatless. Though many individuals are choosing
to go vegetarian, globally, meat eating
is still on the rise. This trend spells trouble for our climate. Even if we suddenly stopped burning
fossil fuels, business as usual food systems paired
with a growing population would push global temperatures over 1.5°C
by the end of the century. Cattle are the biggest culprit. Beef and dairy production are responsible
for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18%
of the world's calories. In fact, diets containing modest portions
of meats like chicken often produce less greenhouse gas
than vegetarian diets high in dairy. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk
consumption could go a long way toward achieving many of the benefits
of a meatless world— no magic required.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A high dairy vegetarian diet produces less green house gasses than meals with modest meat portions such as chicken.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated reduction in greenhouse gas emissions if all meat were to be removed from our shelves? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 63%, D. 80% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary reason for the increase in produce costs immediately after the removal of meat? Options: A. Decrease in demand for fruits and vegetables, B. Increase in transportation costs, C. Rise in demand for fruits and vegetables, D. Decrease in crop yields Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the impact on the meat industry workers in developing countries after the collapse of the meat industry? Options: A. They are shifted to higher-paying jobs, B. They are left scrambling for income, C. They are unaffected by the change, D. They are shifted to agricultural crops Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the long-term effect on the cost of vegetarianism compared to meat-eating in most countries? Options: A. Vegetarianism becomes more expensive, B. Vegetarianism becomes less expensive, C. The cost remains the same, D. The cost is dependent on the region Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the impact on land use after the removal of animals raised for meat? Options: A. More land is required for agriculture, B. Less land is required for agriculture, C. The same amount of land is required for agriculture, D. Land is converted to urban areas Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is one of the health benefits of a meatless diet? Options: A. Lower rates of heart disease, B. Higher rates of cancer, C. Increased risk of respiratory diseases, D. Decreased risk of influenza Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the impact on global biodiversity after the removal of animals raised for meat? Options: A. Global biodiversity decreases, B. Global biodiversity remains the same, C. Global biodiversity rises, D. The impact is dependent on the region Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary reason for the increase in global temperatures even if fossil fuel burning is stopped? Options: A. Business as usual food systems paired with a growing population, B. Increase in vegetarian diets, C. Decrease in meat consumption, D. Increase in renewable energy sources Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the estimated percentage of food-based emissions attributed to beef and dairy production? Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is one way to achieve the benefits of a meatless world without completely removing meat from our diets? Options: A. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk consumption, B. Increasing chicken consumption, C. Decreasing fish consumption, D. Increasing dairy consumption Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

Question 10: What is one way to achieve the benefits of a meatless world without completely removing meat from our diets? Options: A. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk consumption, B. Increasing chicken consumption, C. Decreasing fish consumption, D. Increasing dairy consumption

This question is related to the ground truth MCQ, which states that a high dairy vegetarian diet produces more greenhouse gases than meals with modest meat portions such as chicken. The correct option in Question 10 (A. Reducing beef, cheese, and milk consumption) implies that reducing dairy consumption can help achieve the benefits of a meatless world, which aligns with the intent of the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Rosa Parks’s husband Raymond Parks was in a group that advocated for the case related to
Options: A. Emmett Till, B. The Scottsboro Boys, C. Recy Taylor
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year did Rosa Parks travel to rural Alabama to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been sexually assaulted by six white men? Options: A. 1943, B. 1944, C. 1955, D. 1957 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What organization did Rosa Parks represent when she met with Recy Taylor? Options: A. National Association for the Advancement of Women, B. National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, C. National Civil Rights Association, D. American Civil Liberties Union Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the outcome of the initial trial of Recy Taylor's attackers? Options: A. The attackers were found guilty and sentenced to life in prison., B. The attackers were found not guilty due to lack of evidence., C. The jury failed to indict the attackers., D. The trial was postponed due to a technicality. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was Rosa Parks' role in the Montgomery chapter of the NAACP? Options: A. President, B. Secretary, C. Treasurer, D. Vice President Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the name of Rosa Parks' husband, who was also involved in the NAACP? Options: A. Raymond Parks, B. Johnnie Rebecca Carr, C. Emmet Till, D. John Conyers Correct Option: None
Question 6: What event in 1955 helped ignite the grassroots civil rights movement? Options: A. Rosa Parks' refusal to move to the back of a segregated bus, B. The murder of Emmet Till, C. The desegregation of public transport, D. The election of John Conyers to Congress Correct Option: None
Question 7: How long did the Montgomery bus boycott last? Options: A. 24 hours, B. 381 days, C. 1 year, D. 5 years Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the outcome of the Supreme Court ruling in 1956 regarding public transport? Options: A. The court ruled in favor of segregating public transport., B. The court ruled in favor of desegregating public transport., C. The court postponed the decision due to a technicality., D. The court ruled that the issue was a state matter. Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why did Rosa Parks move to Detroit in 1957? Options: A. She was hired by Congressman John Conyers to help support his civil rights campaigns., B. She was unable to find work in Montgomery due to her political reputation., C. She wanted to be closer to her family., D. Both A and B Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the name of the institute Rosa Parks established in her late husband's memory? Options: A. The Raymond Parks Institute for Civil Rights, B. The Rosa Parks Institute for Education, C. The NAACP Institute for Youth Education, D. The transcript does not mention the specific name of the institute. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

However, since none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ, it would be more accurate to say that there is no matching MCQ.

But if I had to choose, I would say:

decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

Options: A. Elaine Steele, B. Johnnie Rebecca Carr, C. Recy Taylor
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating 
public transport. But this victory for the movement 
had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death 
threats throughout the campaign, and was unable to find work in Montgomery
because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning 
civil rights campaigns. Ever vigilant in the fight against racial 
inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 6

**Transcript**:
In 1944, 11 years before her fateful 
decision on a Montgomery Bus, Rosa Parks was investigating 
a vicious crime. As an emissary for 
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, she had traveled to rural Alabama 
to meet with Recy Taylor, a young woman who had been 
sexually assaulted by six white men. It would be difficult enough to convince
an Alabama court that even one of these men was guilty, but Rosa was undeterred. She formed a committee to defend 
Recy in court, flooding the media with testimony and sparking protests 
throughout the South. When a jury failed 
to indict the attackers, Parks demanded the governor 
assemble a new grand jury. She wrote, “I know that you will not fail
to let the people of Alabama know that there is equal justice 
for all of our citizens.” Throughout her life, Parks repeatedly 
challenged racial violence and the prejudiced systems 
protecting its perpetrators. But this work came at an enormous risk— and a personal price. Born in 1913, Rosa was raised by her 
mother and grandparents in rural Alabama. But outside this loving home, the fear 
of racial violence cast a long shadow. The Ku Klux Klan frequently 
drove past their home, and Jim Crow laws 
segregated public spaces. At 19 she settled in Montgomery
and married Raymond Parks, a barber who shared her growing fury 
at racial injustice. He was involved with the local chapter
of the NAACP; a role many avoided 
for fear of persecution. At first Raymond was eager 
to keep Rosa safe from the potential dangers of activism. But as she grew more incensed at the
limitations imposed on African Americans, she could no longer stand by. When she officially joined 
the NAACP in 1943, Parks and Johnnie Rebecca Carr were 
the only women in the Montgomery chapter. She began keeping minutes 
for their meetings, and soon found herself elected 
secretary of the chapter— formally beginning her secret double life. By day, Rosa worked as a seamstress
to support her mother and husband. By night, she researched and documented
numerous civil rights cases, from local policy disputes to high-profile
murder cases and hate crimes. As secretary, she prepared public 
responses on behalf of the Montgomery chapter,
battling the harsh sentencing, false accusation and smear campaigns 
frequently used against African Americans. In addition to her legal work, Parks 
was a brilliant local strategist. As advisor to the NAACP 
youth group council, she helped young people navigate 
segregated systems including voter registration and 
whites-only libraries. Through the cover of the NAACP, Parks strived to bring clandestine 
civil rights activities into the open. She advocated for civil disobedience
training and spoke out against racial violence,
particularly the murder of Emmet Till. In 1955, her refusal to move 
to the back of a segregated bus helped ignite the grassroots movement 
she had hoped for. Parks was arrested and jailed 
for her one-woman protest, where she was visited by local activists. Together they planned a twenty-four 
hour bus boycott. It lasted for three hundred 
and eighty-one days. Park’s simple act had transformed 
nascent civil rights activism into a national movement. In 1956, the boycott ended 
when the Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating

had come at a great cost. Rosa had been receiving vicious death

because of her political reputation. In 1957, she moved to Detroit 
to continue working as a seamstress, until being hired by Congressman 
John Conyers to help support his burgeoning

inequality, Parks remained active 
for the next 40 years. She wrote several books, traveled across the country giving talks
to support other activists, and established an institute 
for the education of young people in her late husband’s memory. Today, Rosa Parks is remembered 
as a radical spirit who railed against the most powerful 
people and policies. Her call to action continues to resound: “knowing what must be done
does away with fear.”

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1830 at a clothing store
near the Boston Harbor, David Walker carefully stitched
a pamphlet into the lining of a sailor’s coat. The volume was thin enough
to be completely hidden, but its content was 
far from insubstantial. In fact, at the time, many members 
of the US government considered this pamphlet to be one 
of the most dangerous documents in American history. So to ensure this volume
reached his audience, Walker had to hide his work 
in the clothing of both willing co-conspirators 
and unknowing sailors; smuggling the pamphlet 
throughout the country. But what was this incendiary document? 
And who exactly was the man who wrote it? Son of an enslaved father
and a freedwoman, David Walker was born free 
in the late 18th century in Wilmington, North Carolina. From a young age, he sought to extend 
his freedom to all Black Americans, and after moving to Charleston
as a young man, he became closely involved with the
African Methodist Episcopal Church. At that time, the mainstream movement 
to end slavery was comprised of societies led by wealthy white men 
who favored gradual change and avoided confrontation
with slaveholders. But the AME Church practiced
a more radical brand of abolition. In 1822, AME leader Denmark Vesey
planned a major insurrection intended to violently liberate 
Charleston’s enslaved community and set the city ablaze. It’s unclear if Walker contributed
to Vesey’s plan, but he wasn’t among the many AME members
who were arrested and executed for this attempted rebellion. In 1825, Walker surfaced in Boston, where
he rejoined the fight against slavery. In addition to marrying 
fellow activist Eliza Butler and opening his clothing store, Walker helped fund America’s
first Black-owned newspaper. Is passionate articles and public speeches
sought to instill pride and camaraderie into those fighting for Black liberation. But to truly unite free 
and enslaved Black Americans, Walker would have to go beyond Boston. In 1829, he poured his ideas into the “Appeal to the Colored Citizens 
of the World.” This treatise was punctuated
with furious exclamation marks and emphasized the spiritual righteousness
of resistance. He described the suffering of enslaved
people in graphic detail to prove that the reality for Black Americans
was often “kill or be killed.” And given these circumstances, Walker staunchly defended 
the right to militant action. This wasn’t his only departure 
from moderate mainstream abolitionists. To stress the importance
of Black solidarity, Walker connected American abolitionism with global movements 
for Black liberation. He called for an international 
Black freedom struggle in an early display of what would come
to be called Pan-Africanism. But at the same time, 
he opposed the popular movement for Black Americans to emigrate to Africa. While the “Appeal” criticized 
the Founding Fathers for their hypocrisy, Walker insisted that Black people were
essential to the country’s creation, and had an undeniable right
to American citizenship. Walker suspected 
these incendiary arguments would make him a target for violence. But in spite of the danger, he continued 
using sailors to smuggle his work. The “Appeal” traveled down the coast 
into the hands of shopkeepers, church leaders, political organizers, 
and underground abolitionist networks. For these readers, Walker’s words
galvanized militant efforts to overthrow slave owners and its call to arms struck fear
into white officials. Police intercepted its delivery, and quarantined Black sailors
at Southern ports. The pamphlet inspired Louisiana 
to ban anti-slavery literature, and both North and South Carolina 
cracked down on Black education to prevent literacy 
among enslaved peoples. Southern officials even placed 
a bounty on Walker’s head worth the modern equivalent
of $322,000. But while friends urged him to flee,
Walker refused to abandon his cause. Tragically, his bravery 
couldn’t protect him from the deadliest disease of his time. In August 1830, Walker was found dead. And while his associates declared
him the victim of assassination, it’s now widely believed 
that he died from tuberculosis. Following his death, Walker's message
continued to resound. Frederick Douglass credited him 
as the originator of radical abolitionism, and his “Appeal” inspired some 
of the most influential members of the 20th century liberation movement. From Malcolm X’s militant approach
to Black resistance, to James Cone’s writing
on Black spirituality, Walker’s legacy remains
crucially important to the history of Black resistance movements— and their visions for the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: David Walker distributed his "Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the World" from the abolitionist hotbed of _______.
Options: A. Charleston, B. New York City, C. Boston, D. Phoenix
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was David Walker's occupation in Boston? Options: A. Sailor, B. Clothing store owner, C. Newspaper editor, D. Church leader Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the name of the document written by David Walker in 1829? Options: A. "The Abolitionist's Guide", B. "Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the World", C. "The Black Liberation Manifesto", D. "The End of Slavery" Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the main goal of David Walker's "Appeal"? Options: A. To promote gradual change and avoid confrontation with slaveholders, B. To unite free and enslaved Black Americans and instill pride and camaraderie, C. To advocate for Black emigration to Africa, D. To criticize the Founding Fathers for their hypocrisy Correct Option: None
Question 4: How did David Walker distribute his "Appeal"? Options: A. Through public speeches and newspaper articles, B. By smuggling it through sailors and clothing, C. Through the African Methodist Episcopal Church, D. By mailing it to abolitionist networks Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the reaction of Southern officials to David Walker's "Appeal"? Options: A. They ignored it and considered it insignificant, B. They intercepted its delivery and quarantined Black sailors, C. They praised it and considered it a valuable contribution to the abolitionist movement, D. They banned it but did not take any further action Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the bounty placed on David Walker's head by Southern officials? Options: A. $100, B. $1,000, C. $10,000, D. The modern equivalent of $322,000 Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the cause of David Walker's death? Options: A. Assassination, B. Tuberculosis, C. Old age, D. Unknown Correct Option: None
Question 8: Who credited David Walker as the originator of radical abolitionism? Options: A. Frederick Douglass, B. Malcolm X, C. James Cone, D. Denmark Vesey Correct Option: None
Question 9: What movement did David Walker's "Appeal" inspire? Options: A. The Civil Rights Movement, B. The Black Power Movement, C. The 20th-century liberation movement, D. The Abolitionist Movement Correct Option: None
Question 10: What concept did David Walker's "Appeal" emphasize, which would later be called Pan-Africanism? Options: A. The importance of Black solidarity within the United States, B. The connection between American abolitionism and global movements for Black liberation, C. The need for Black emigration to Africa, D. The importance of gradual change and avoiding confrontation with slaveholders Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the content and intent of the questions, the most similar generated MCQ would be Question 4: "How did David Walker distribute his 'Appeal'?" 

Although this question does not directly ask about the location from which the "Appeal" was distributed, one of the options (B) mentions smuggling through sailors and clothing, which is related to the fact that David Walker distributed his "Appeal" from Boston, as mentioned in the ground truth MCQ.

However, a more suitable generated MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ would be one that directly asks about the location from which the "Appeal" was distributed. Since none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ, I will provide the index of the generated MCQ that is most closely related to the topic.

Index: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1830 at a clothing store
near the Boston Harbor, David Walker carefully stitched
a pamphlet into the lining of a sailor’s coat. The volume was thin enough
to be completely hidden, but its content was 
far from insubstantial. In fact, at the time, many members 
of the US government considered this pamphlet to be one 
of the most dangerous documents in American history. So to ensure this volume
reached his audience, Walker had to hide his work 
in the clothing of both willing co-conspirators 
and unknowing sailors; smuggling the pamphlet 
throughout the country. But what was this incendiary document? 
And who exactly was the man who wrote it? Son of an enslaved father
and a freedwoman, David Walker was born free 
in the late 18th century in Wilmington, North Carolina. From a young age, he sought to extend 
his freedom to all Black Americans, and after moving to Charleston
as a young man, he became closely involved with the
African Methodist Episcopal Church. At that time, the mainstream movement 
to end slavery was comprised of societies led by wealthy white men 
who favored gradual change and avoided confrontation
with slaveholders. But the AME Church practiced
a more radical brand of abolition. In 1822, AME leader Denmark Vesey
planned a major insurrection intended to violently liberate 
Charleston’s enslaved community and set the city ablaze. It’s unclear if Walker contributed
to Vesey’s plan, but he wasn’t among the many AME members
who were arrested and executed for this attempted rebellion. In 1825, Walker surfaced in Boston, where
he rejoined the fight against slavery. In addition to marrying 
fellow activist Eliza Butler and opening his clothing store, Walker helped fund America’s
first Black-owned newspaper. Is passionate articles and public speeches
sought to instill pride and camaraderie into those fighting for Black liberation. But to truly unite free 
and enslaved Black Americans, Walker would have to go beyond Boston. In 1829, he poured his ideas into the “Appeal to the Colored Citizens 
of the World.” This treatise was punctuated
with furious exclamation marks and emphasized the spiritual righteousness
of resistance. He described the suffering of enslaved
people in graphic detail to prove that the reality for Black Americans
was often “kill or be killed.” And given these circumstances, Walker staunchly defended 
the right to militant action. This wasn’t his only departure 
from moderate mainstream abolitionists. To stress the importance
of Black solidarity, Walker connected American abolitionism with global movements 
for Black liberation. He called for an international 
Black freedom struggle in an early display of what would come
to be called Pan-Africanism. But at the same time, 
he opposed the popular movement for Black Americans to emigrate to Africa. While the “Appeal” criticized 
the Founding Fathers for their hypocrisy, Walker insisted that Black people were
essential to the country’s creation, and had an undeniable right
to American citizenship. Walker suspected 
these incendiary arguments would make him a target for violence. But in spite of the danger, he continued 
using sailors to smuggle his work. The “Appeal” traveled down the coast 
into the hands of shopkeepers, church leaders, political organizers, 
and underground abolitionist networks. For these readers, Walker’s words
galvanized militant efforts to overthrow slave owners and its call to arms struck fear
into white officials. Police intercepted its delivery, and quarantined Black sailors
at Southern ports. The pamphlet inspired Louisiana 
to ban anti-slavery literature, and both North and South Carolina 
cracked down on Black education to prevent literacy 
among enslaved peoples. Southern officials even placed 
a bounty on Walker’s head worth the modern equivalent
of $322,000. But while friends urged him to flee,
Walker refused to abandon his cause. Tragically, his bravery 
couldn’t protect him from the deadliest disease of his time. In August 1830, Walker was found dead. And while his associates declared
him the victim of assassination, it’s now widely believed 
that he died from tuberculosis. Following his death, Walker's message
continued to resound. Frederick Douglass credited him 
as the originator of radical abolitionism, and his “Appeal” inspired some 
of the most influential members of the 20th century liberation movement. From Malcolm X’s militant approach
to Black resistance, to James Cone’s writing
on Black spirituality, Walker’s legacy remains
crucially important to the history of Black resistance movements— and their visions for the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The political backlash against Walker’s "Appeal" included which of the following legislative responses in the American South?
Options: A. Abolition of slavery, B. Anti-literacy laws, C. Fugitive Slave Act, D. Indentured Servitude Act
Correct Option: B

Question 3: What was the main goal of David Walker's "Appeal"? Options: A. To promote gradual change and avoid confrontation with slaveholders, B. To unite free and enslaved Black Americans and instill pride and camaraderie, C. To advocate for Black emigration to Africa, D. To criticize the Founding Fathers for their hypocrisy Correct Option: None

They intercepted its delivery and quarantined Black sailors, C. They praised it and considered it a valuable contribution to the abolitionist movement, D. The connection between American abolitionism and global movements for Black liberation, C. The need for Black emigration to Africa, D. The importance of gradual change and avoiding confrontation with slaveholders Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the reaction of Southern officials to David Walker's "Appeal". The correct option for Question 5, "They intercepted its delivery and quarantined Black sailors", is closely related to the correct option for the ground truth MCQ, "Anti-literacy laws", as both options describe the backlash against Walker's "Appeal" in the American South.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1830 at a clothing store
near the Boston Harbor, David Walker carefully stitched
a pamphlet into the lining of a sailor’s coat. The volume was thin enough
to be completely hidden, but its content was 
far from insubstantial. In fact, at the time, many members 
of the US government considered this pamphlet to be one 
of the most dangerous documents in American history. So to ensure this volume
reached his audience, Walker had to hide his work 
in the clothing of both willing co-conspirators 
and unknowing sailors; smuggling the pamphlet 
throughout the country. But what was this incendiary document? 
And who exactly was the man who wrote it? Son of an enslaved father
and a freedwoman, David Walker was born free 
in the late 18th century in Wilmington, North Carolina. From a young age, he sought to extend 
his freedom to all Black Americans, and after moving to Charleston
as a young man, he became closely involved with the
African Methodist Episcopal Church. At that time, the mainstream movement 
to end slavery was comprised of societies led by wealthy white men 
who favored gradual change and avoided confrontation
with slaveholders. But the AME Church practiced
a more radical brand of abolition. In 1822, AME leader Denmark Vesey
planned a major insurrection intended to violently liberate 
Charleston’s enslaved community and set the city ablaze. It’s unclear if Walker contributed
to Vesey’s plan, but he wasn’t among the many AME members
who were arrested and executed for this attempted rebellion. In 1825, Walker surfaced in Boston, where
he rejoined the fight against slavery. In addition to marrying 
fellow activist Eliza Butler and opening his clothing store, Walker helped fund America’s
first Black-owned newspaper. Is passionate articles and public speeches
sought to instill pride and camaraderie into those fighting for Black liberation. But to truly unite free 
and enslaved Black Americans, Walker would have to go beyond Boston. In 1829, he poured his ideas into the “Appeal to the Colored Citizens 
of the World.” This treatise was punctuated
with furious exclamation marks and emphasized the spiritual righteousness
of resistance. He described the suffering of enslaved
people in graphic detail to prove that the reality for Black Americans
was often “kill or be killed.” And given these circumstances, Walker staunchly defended 
the right to militant action. This wasn’t his only departure 
from moderate mainstream abolitionists. To stress the importance
of Black solidarity, Walker connected American abolitionism with global movements 
for Black liberation. He called for an international 
Black freedom struggle in an early display of what would come
to be called Pan-Africanism. But at the same time, 
he opposed the popular movement for Black Americans to emigrate to Africa. While the “Appeal” criticized 
the Founding Fathers for their hypocrisy, Walker insisted that Black people were
essential to the country’s creation, and had an undeniable right
to American citizenship. Walker suspected 
these incendiary arguments would make him a target for violence. But in spite of the danger, he continued 
using sailors to smuggle his work. The “Appeal” traveled down the coast 
into the hands of shopkeepers, church leaders, political organizers, 
and underground abolitionist networks. For these readers, Walker’s words
galvanized militant efforts to overthrow slave owners and its call to arms struck fear
into white officials. Police intercepted its delivery, and quarantined Black sailors
at Southern ports. The pamphlet inspired Louisiana 
to ban anti-slavery literature, and both North and South Carolina 
cracked down on Black education to prevent literacy 
among enslaved peoples. Southern officials even placed 
a bounty on Walker’s head worth the modern equivalent
of $322,000. But while friends urged him to flee,
Walker refused to abandon his cause. Tragically, his bravery 
couldn’t protect him from the deadliest disease of his time. In August 1830, Walker was found dead. And while his associates declared
him the victim of assassination, it’s now widely believed 
that he died from tuberculosis. Following his death, Walker's message
continued to resound. Frederick Douglass credited him 
as the originator of radical abolitionism, and his “Appeal” inspired some 
of the most influential members of the 20th century liberation movement. From Malcolm X’s militant approach
to Black resistance, to James Cone’s writing
on Black spirituality, Walker’s legacy remains
crucially important to the history of Black resistance movements— and their visions for the future.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
In 1830 at a clothing store
near the Boston Harbor, David Walker carefully stitched
a pamphlet into the lining of a sailor’s coat. The volume was thin enough
to be completely hidden, but its content was 
far from insubstantial. In fact, at the time, many members 
of the US government considered this pamphlet to be one 
of the most dangerous documents in American history. So to ensure this volume
reached his audience, Walker had to hide his work 
in the clothing of both willing co-conspirators 
and unknowing sailors; smuggling the pamphlet 
throughout the country. But what was this incendiary document? 
And who exactly was the man who wrote it? Son of an enslaved father
and a freedwoman, David Walker was born free 
in the late 18th century in Wilmington, North Carolina. From a young age, he sought to extend 
his freedom to all Black Americans, and after moving to Charleston
as a young man, he became closely involved with the
African Methodist Episcopal Church. At that time, the mainstream movement 
to end slavery was comprised of societies led by wealthy white men 
who favored gradual change and avoided confrontation
with slaveholders. But the AME Church practiced
a more radical brand of abolition. In 1822, AME leader Denmark Vesey

sought to instill pride and camaraderie into those fighting for Black liberation. But to truly unite free 
and enslaved Black Americans, Walker would have to go beyond Boston. In 1829, he poured his ideas into the “Appeal to the Colored Citizens 
of the World.” This treatise was punctuated
with furious exclamation marks and emphasized the spiritual righteousness
of resistance. He described the suffering of enslaved

was often “kill or be killed.” And given these circumstances, Walker staunchly defended

to be called Pan-Africanism. But at the same time,

essential to the country’s creation, and had an undeniable right
to American citizenship. Walker suspected 
these incendiary arguments would make him a target for violence. But in spite of the danger, he continued

as the originator of radical abolitionism, and his “Appeal” inspired some

to Black resistance, to James Cone’s writing
on Black spirituality, Walker’s legacy remains
crucially important to the history of Black resistance movements— and their visions for the future.
